title: 110_hr986
content: The Act is titled the "Eightmile Wild and Scenic River Act" and designates the Eightmile River in Connecticut as a Wild and Scenic River. The Eightmile River in Connecticut was studied for potential inclusion in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System due to its free-flowing condition and outstanding resource values, including cultural landscape, water quality, unique species, and geology. The Eightmile River watershed's resource values depend on its integrity and quality, making the watershed as a whole important for designation. The study committee took a watershed approach and prepared a comprehensive management plan with assistance from the National Park Service. The Eightmile River watershed management plan, dated December 8, 2005, establishes objectives, standards, and action programs for long-term protection of the river's values. The plan includes a recommendation for inclusion in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. The residents and officials of towns along the Eightmile River in Connecticut endorsed the watershed management plan and sought designation of the river as part of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. The State of Connecticut also passed Public Act 05-18 to support this initiative. The Eightmile River in Connecticut, totaling approximately 25.3 miles, will be administered by the Secretary of the Interior. This includes a 10.8-mile scenic segment of the main stem, an 8.0-mile scenic segment of the East Branch, and a 3.9-mile segment of Harris Brook. The Eightmile River in Connecticut, totaling 25.3 miles, will be managed as a scenic river. This includes segments of Beaver Brook, Falls Brook, and other tributaries, in accordance with the Eightmile River Watershed Management Plan. The Eightmile River in Connecticut, totaling 25.3 miles, will be managed as a scenic river. The Eightmile River Watershed Management Plan satisfies the requirements for a comprehensive management plan under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. The Secretary of the Interior will coordinate management responsibilities with the Eightmile River Coordinating Committee. Cooperative agreements may be entered into for the protection, preservation, and enhancement of the river. The Eightmile River in Connecticut will not be part of the National Park System and will be managed in cooperation with the State of Connecticut, towns of Salem, Lyme, and East Haddam, and local organizations. Zoning ordinances in effect as of December 8, 2005, will include provisions for conservation of floodplains, wetlands, and watercourses associated with the river. The Eightmile River in Connecticut will be managed in cooperation with the State of Connecticut, towns of Salem, Lyme, and East Haddam, and local organizations. Zoning ordinances will include provisions for conservation of floodplains, wetlands, and watercourses. The segments designated by subsection (b) will be subject to the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. The Secretary's authority to acquire lands for this purpose is limited to donation or consent of the owner, following the Eightmile River Watershed Management Plan. The Eightmile River watershed management plan recognizes specific tributaries as crucial for protecting and enhancing the river. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out this plan. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 31, 2007.
